function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Minimizing forest edges and designing trails far from forest patches may reduce wildlife protection and mental health benefits while allowing human immersion in nature.","Impact":"Loss of wildlife habitat and decreased mental health benefits from nature immersion.","Mitigation":"Careful planning and design of trails to minimize disturbance to forest patches while still allowing for human interaction with nature.","Technologies":"Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for trail planning and design.","People":"Wildlife populations, individuals seeking mental health benefits from nature immersion.","Owner":"Environmental planners, park managers, mental health professionals."},{"Description":"Intensive vegetation management for mental health benefits may be detrimental to wildlife, leading to an increase in urban exploiter species.","Impact":"Negative impact on wildlife populations and ecosystems due to intensive vegetation management.","Mitigation":"Balancing vegetation management to support both mental health benefits and wildlife habitat, avoiding excessive removal of natural habitat features.","Technologies":"Ecological modeling to understand the impact of vegetation management on wildlife.","People":"Urban planners, mental health professionals, ecologists.","Owner":"Urban planning agencies, mental health facilities, conservation organizations."},{"Description":"Human aesthetic preferences in green spaces may negatively impact urban wildlife support, leading to a potential conflict between human preferences and wildlife habitat needs.","Impact":"Loss of urban wildlife habitat and species diversity due to conflicting human aesthetic preferences.","Mitigation":"Educating the public about the importance of supporting urban wildlife, incorporating wildlife-friendly design principles into urban green spaces.","Technologies":"Augmented reality tools for public education and visualization of wildlife-friendly design.","People":"Urban residents, landscape architects, conservationists.","Owner":"Local government, community organizations, conservation groups."},{"Description":"Presence of dogs in green spaces can disrupt wildlife activity patterns, but walking dogs is a common motivation for people to visit green spaces.","Impact":"Disruption of wildlife activity patterns and potential stress for wildlife due to the presence of dogs in green spaces.","Mitigation":"Establishing guidelines and rules for dog owners to minimize the impact on wildlife, providing designated areas for dog walking that minimize wildlife disturbance.","Technologies":"Geolocation and mapping tools for designating dog-friendly areas in green spaces.","People":"Dog owners, wildlife enthusiasts, park visitors.","Owner":"Park management, local government, wildlife conservation organizations."},{"Description":"Management of decorative vegetation can impact wildlife support and the restorative potential of green spaces.","Impact":"Loss of wildlife habitat and reduced restorative potential of green spaces due to inappropriate management of decorative vegetation.","Mitigation":"Promote the use of native and pollinator-friendly plants in decorative landscaping, incorporate wildlife-friendly features into decorative vegetation management.","Technologies":"Database management systems for identifying native plant species and pollinator-friendly plants.","People":"Gardeners, landscape designers, park managers.","Owner":"Local government, park management, neighborhood associations."}]}
